answers.author: Megan Bourke
answers.text:
Downers Grove, Illinois, has a great public CIP status section of its website. This may provide some initial groundwork. When I worked there, projects were updated weekly as necessary.
http://www.downers.us/construction-updates

answers.author: Leslie Beauregard
answers.text:
Charlottesville has a monthly CIP meeting that's mostly staff but Council does receive the reports.  It's a very good summary of current projects and those that are in planning stages.  I have attached a recent report.

answers.author: Mark Abeles-Allison
answers.text:
My number one suggestion would be to have a long term plan, at least five years.  Here is the link to GFOA's budget recommendation for long range capital improvement planning.  It is a good place to start.  
http://www.gfoa.org/downloads/EDCPMulti-YearCapitalPlanning.pdf

author: Trevor Henry
text:
Looking for input/feeback on best practices/examples for providing periodic Capital Project status updates to our Board of Supervisors, including details (i.e. scope/schedule/budget, format, method of delivery, lessons learned, etc.). Do you have any examples that you would be willing to share? 
Thanks!
title: Capital Project Review with Board of Supervisors
